intro: Loasa chuquitensis, commonly known as the Andean loasa, is a shrub native to the high-altitude regions of South America, particularly in Peru and Bolivia. It belongs to the Malvaceae family and is characterized by its dense, woody structure and small, clustered flowers. The plant typically grows in rocky or alpine environments, adapting to the harsh conditions of the Andes. Its leaves are usually narrow and hairy, while its flowers are often pink or white, attracting pollinators such as bees and butterflies. Loasa chuquitensis plays a role in local ecosystems and has been studied for its potential medicinal properties.
